Empires and Puzzles Leafwhisk Review: The Enchanter of Beasts

Leafwhisk might look like he is just playing a tune, but this Goblin brings a massive Spotted Boar to the battlefield. With incredible defense growth and a Mega Minion that acts as a second health bar, he is a deceptively sturdy tank. Discover if this flute-playing enchanter is the defensive anchor your roster needs or just bacon waiting to be fried.
Leafwhisk: The Pied Piper of Piglets
Leafwhisk, The Flute-Playing Fortress: Defense Growth and Mega Pigs

Leafwhisk is a 5-star Legendary Nature hero from the Goblin family, originally released in late 2023. As a Paladin, his primary role is to ensure the survival of his team through massive damage mitigation and the summoning of a substantial Mega Minion. While the Goblin family is notorious for its aggressive Withers and Growths, Leafwhisk takes a decidedly more protective approach. He is not the hero who will wipe the enemy team in seconds, but he is the one who ensures your team is still standing five minutes later.

The artwork for Leafwhisk captures a whimsical yet mischievous goblin Bard. Clad in a tattered hat with colorful feathers and playing a simple wooden flute, he exudes a deceptive harmlessness. The green skin and sharp features are classic Goblin, but the musical theme sets him apart from the more brutal warriors of his kin. He looks like the kind of character who would lead you on a merry chase through the woods, only for you to realize you have been led straight into a boar pen.

When analyzing Leafwhisk's stats in the context of late 2025, it is undeniable that he has fallen behind the power creep curve. Modern heroes, such as those from the Titan Hunter or Temple Summons, boast base Power levels soaring past 1250, with attack and defense stats regularly exceeding 1300. Leafwhisk sits at a modest 980 Power (1180 with Limit Break 2). His base defense of 1021 and health of 1584 are serviceable but no longer elite. However, his "Growth" mechanic is critical here; unlike standard buffs, Growth modifies his base stats, allowing him to artificially inflate his toughness to somewhat competitive levels during a match.
is a purely defensive skill with a unique twist. At Average speed, Leafwhisk provides two main benefits:

A massive +355 defense increase for all allies. This is "Growth," meaning it modifies the stat directly and cannot be dispelled by standard means, only countered by "Wither." This instantly makes the entire team significantly harder to kill with tile damage or physical strikes.
He summons a Mega Minion for himself. This is not your average minion; it inherits a staggering 65% of his HP and deals 260% attack damage.
The Mega Minion grants the owner immunity to buff dispels. This is a crucial utility, protecting your other buffs (like taunt or attack up) from being stripped away as long as the pig survives.
Let us break down the mathematics of the Flute of Enchantment to understand its true potential.
Average speed requires 10 tiles to charge (9 with mana troops/bonuses). In a fast-paced meta, this can feel slow for a defensive hero, but the payoff is substantial.
With a maxed Leafwhisk (LB2, roughly 1953 HP), the Mega Minion inherits 65% of that. That is approximately
. If you add troop bonuses, this "meat shield" can easily exceed 1,500 HP. Essentially, killing Leafwhisk requires chewing through two health bars.

The minion hits for 260% of Leafwhisk's attack. With an LB2 attack of roughly 1226, the minion hits harder than many older heroes' special skills, and it does this automatically at the end of every turn.

The +355 defense is a flat addition. For a hero with 1000 defense, this is a 35.5% increase. For a glass cannon with 700 defense, it is a 50% increase. This disproportionately benefits squishy allies, making them surprisingly tanky.
Family Bonus, Passives, Aether Power & Unique Abilities
The Goblin family brings a distinct set of mechanics that revolve around modifying stats rather than just buffing them.

The Goblin family bonus is not listed in standard data, but typically Goblins operate individually with their Growth/Wither mechanics. The key interaction here is that his Defense Growth overwrites Defense Wither, allowing him to cleanse his team of permanent defense down effects caused by enemy Goblins.

Leafwhisk possesses a 50% chance on casting his special to deal 90% damage to all enemies and inflict -25% accuracy. This "blind" effect is incredibly valuable for survival. While 50% is a coin toss, when it lands, it can completely neutralize enemy slash attacks and specials, adding another layer of mitigation to his kit.

is the chosen Aether Power. Given his role as a damage sponge, this fits perfectly. At the start of the battle, he gets a defense boost that helps him survive until he can cast his first flute solo. It synergizes well with his high base defense and paladin class.
Leafwhisk was released during the "Goblin Era," a time when the game introduced the Wither and Growth mechanics that permanently altered hero stats.

Upon release, he was often overshadowed by his more aggressive family members like Acidfire and Darkfeather. Players often viewed him as "passive" because he didn't kill the enemy directly. However, those who used him realized he created a "wall" that was incredibly frustrating to break.

Stat-wise, he is dusty. The 300-point power gap between him and late-2025 heroes is significant. However, the mechanic of a 65% HP Mega Minion scales with his HP. If you can boost his HP (through troops or team synergies), his relevance remains intact because that Mega Minion is essentially a 6th team member.

He is no longer a top-tier war tank due to the prevalence of "Minion/Mega Minion Removers" and extremely high-damage fast heroes. However, he remains a viable flank in wars and is excellent in PvE content where survivability is key. He serves as a strong counter to heavy dispel teams.

As of this writing, Leafwhisk does not have a costume. This section reviews the base hero. Should a costume be released, it would likely need to address his speed or add a direct healing component to bring him back to the top of the meta.
Leafwhisk is a Paladin, which is the premier defensive class. The goal is simple: maximize Health and Defense.
Prioritize every Health node, then Defense. Ignore Attack.

Maximizes the HP of the Spotted Boar Mega Minion. Since the minion inherits 65% of HP, every point of health you give Leafwhisk is partially given to his minion. High defense makes the "Growth" even more effective.
His tile damage will be negligible.
Increases the damage of the Mega Minion's hit (260% of Attack).
Not recommended. Leafwhisk's job is to stay alive, not to deal tile damage. A dead Leafwhisk summons no pigs.
path is the correct choice. You want that Mega Minion to be as fat as possible to absorb damage for Leafwhisk.
Between the Paladin talent, high defense stats, Defense Growth, and a massive Mega Minion, he is very hard to take down.
The Mega Minion protects his buffs (and himself) from being dispelled. This is excellent against heroes who rely on stripping buffs before hitting.
The +355 defense is Growth, meaning it stays until the battle ends or it is overwritten by Wither. It does not wear off after a few turns.
The boar hits surprisingly hard for a passive effect, helping to chip away at enemies.
He does not win matches; he stops you from losing them. If the rest of your team dies, Leafwhisk will just die slowly afterwards.
Heroes who destroy or steal Mega Minions (like recent hunters or specific anti-minion heroes) completely neutralize his main asset.
In a Very Fast meta, he might die before casting.
He adds virtual health via the minion and mitigation via defense, but he cannot restore red health bars to his allies.
At Very Fast speed, he becomes a nightmare. Getting that Mega Minion up early makes him nearly unkillable.
The permanent Defense Growth shines in long battles where you can stack it (if he had a stack) or just maintain it against waves of enemies. The minion keeps him safe.
He can stall out an attacking team, causing a time-out or forcing them to waste specials on his minion.
Leafwhisk works best in "sustain" teams where the goal is to outlast the opponent.
Using multiple Goblins allows you to stack various Growths. Leafwhisk covers defense, while others cover attack or health. The passive bonuses trigger more often.
Protecting Leafwhisk with a Taunt hero allows him to fire safely. Once the Mega Minion is out, he becomes a secondary tank.
Boosted health sits underneath the Mega Minion. Enemies have to cut through the Minion, then the Boosted Health, then the Base Health, all while facing +355 Defense.
Any hero that destroys Mega Minions instantly removes 50% of Leafwhisk's value.
Heroes that inflict Defense Wither can neutralize his Defense Growth, bringing him back to base stats.
Since he is Average speed, he is prone to being mana-controlled before he can fire.

If you are lucky enough to pull Leafwhisk early, he will carry you through almost all map content. His defense boost effectively makes your 4-star heroes as tough as 5-stars. Put him in the center of your defense or on the flank and focus on keeping him alive with healers.

Leafwhisk is a niche tool for your roster. He is likely not your primary war tank anymore due to stats. However, he is an excellent card to have for depth in wars, especially for clean-up teams or against heavy DoT teams where you just need bodies on the board to soak damage. Do not prioritize Alpha Aethers for him unless you really love the Goblin playstyle or use him in a top-tier Rush defense.
The community reaction to Leafwhisk was mixed, leaning towards "underwhelming" upon release.
noted on the forums, "just another broken goblin," while others called them "meat sacks" compared to the older Costumed Horghall.
Some players argued that "355 defense is a lot" and ensures survival, while others countered that "offenses hit so hard it won't matter."

A common sentiment was frustration when facing him: "MEGA MINION WALLLLLLLL ugh." One user noted that even if he doesn't kill you, the battle can time out because you simply cannot kill him fast enough.
It is noted in forum discussions that he received a balance update to his Mega Minion stats, bumping the attack to make the boar a bit more threatening.

Leafwhisk is the epitome of "slow and steady wins the race." He is not flashy, he does not one-shot enemies, and his stats are starting to show their age. Yet, there is something undeniably effective about a hero who summons a pig with more health than some 4-star heroes. He forces the enemy to waste damage, buys time for your heavy hitters, and plays a tune while doing it. While he may not be the king of the Goblins, he is certainly the gatekeeper of the village.
Verdict: A solid defensive specialist who excels in Rush modes and PvE, but struggles to keep pace with the hyper-aggressive modern meta.
